body:
Thank you for your report.

Please provide a **minimal**, **self-contained**, reproducing test case that shows the problem you are reporting.

Without such a minimal, self-contained, reproducing test case I will not be able to investigate this issue.
@ludeus do you work on a fix?
I think the `getIterator()` method in your example is missing a return statement. Are you sure this example is complete?

> I think the `getIterator()` method in your example is missing a return statement. Are you sure this example is complete?

The `$pdo->query()` will throw a PDOException()

sebastians point is, as soon as phpunit get fixed, your test will not get green.
(or produce different errors because of the missing `return`)

This is not as simple as
```patch
diff --git a/src/Framework/Exception/Exception.php b/src/Framework/Exception/Exception.php
index 9a4d92880..44b860e17 100644
--- a/src/Framework/Exception/Exception.php
+++ b/src/Framework/Exception/Exception.php
@@ -45,7 +45,7 @@ class Exception extends RuntimeException implements \PHPUnit\Exception
      */
     protected array $serializableTrace;

-    public function __construct(string $message = '', int $code = 0, ?Throwable $previous = null)
+    public function __construct(string $message = '', int|string $code = 0, ?Throwable $previous = null)
     {
         parent::__construct($message, $code, $previous);
```
The above would only move the error somewhere else.

PHPUnit's exception classes extend PHP's exception classes such as `RuntimeException`. These exception classes do not support non-integer codes: https://3v4l.org/k7Gb3

To me, the fact that `PDOException` uses/supports string codes is an inconsistency in PHP that I do not know how to deal with.

I doubt that PDO will ever fix its error codes (unless forced to), there's nothing we can do about it, but if we can avoid breaking tests by simply adding an integer cast to the getCode(), I think it's worth it.

instead of `$code = (int) $code;` I think I would use a more explicit `$code = 0;`.
this way we have 2 clear camps. int and string code. not a third: numeric-string.

otherwise LGTM
I would rather fix it in this single place than at any place where an exception is thrown.

rename.from: PHPUnit\Framework\Exception does not handle non-integer error codes (PDOException with 'HY000')
rename.to: `PHPUnit\Framework\Exception` does not handle string error codes (`PDOException` with error code `'HY000'`, for example)
